author: @UKGS1977
text: The comments section is really filled with some of the dumbest people on earth. You don't have to like this song but don't be stupid to think that everyone involved in creating Supernove Love didn't seek the proper permission to legally use, create and reimagine the original musical piece by Ryuichi Sakamoto. Otherwise there would be a lawsuit involved. If you don't like the song, fine then you don't have to listen but don't conflate that to thinking this wasn't done without consent or used illegally, people please don't be that dense in life.

author: @Scientific_commentary
text:
A supernova is a massive explosion that occurs when a star runs out of fuel and collapses. It's one of the most energetic events in the universe and can be billions of times brighter than the sun. 
How it happens
A massive star, at least eight times larger than the sun, reaches the end of its life 
The star's core collapses under its own gravity 
The outer layers of the star are blown off in a shock wave 
What it produces
A shock wave that compresses material and creates new elements, like zinc, silver, gold, and uranium 
A ring-like structure called a shell-type remnant 
Debris that can be incorporated into new stars millions or billions of years later 
How to observe
Supernovas are often seen in other galaxies, but difficult to see in the Milky Way because of dust 
Some supernova events have been detected by amateur astronomers 
Types of supernova Core-collapse supernova, Pair-instability supernova, and Photodisintegration supernova.

author: @NY-ck6yj
text:
This song uses a sample from â€œMerry Christmas Mr. Lawrence,â€ https://youtu.be/z9tECKZ60zk?si=xP-0t8JC4idhb8sV
a piece composed by Ryuichi Sakamoto, who also acted in the movie â€œMerry Christmas Mr.Lawrenceâ€(the same title as the music)
https://youtu.be/6GxiqbFG_Dw?si=24AY02WokT59wjdd  
As a fan of Sakamoto, I feel really sad and disappointed that such a deep and meaningful song was used in a completely different and trivial song.  It feels like the original meaning and value of the music have been lost.  Whatâ€™s even more upsetting is that from now on, every time people hear this melody, theyâ€™ll likely think of IVEâ€™s â€œSupernova Loveâ€ instead of Sakamotoâ€™s masterpiece, and thatâ€™s something Iâ€™m really sad about.

author: @SuperSolonik
text:
Hey guys. Sakamoto would be pleasantly surprised if he heard the work of David Guetta. Why are you all so excited? On the contrary, it is in memory of the great composer who created such a creation as Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence. David and the girls reminded us of him. I think Sakamoto would not mind. Peace and love and bright memory to the musician. From Russia. 
(by the way, 17 years ago, Watergate released the track heart of Asia. That's how I learned about Sakamoto)

author: @ê¹€ìœ ì§„-b4e8e
text: I think haters are overreacting to what should be seen as a tribute to a beautifully scripted chorus. To say that adapting the original melody to a love song is an insult to the original composer is no little different from critics of Christmas hymn-inspired remakes (originally intended to celebrate the birth of Jesus Christ) as crass commercialization of Christian religious traditions. Never knew there were so many Karens from the far east. Reflect on your own wartime mistakes and historical amnesia before pointing fingers at another.

author: @malanoremantavi3435
text:
Okay wait. I must admit that I did not at all expect all this outpouring of anger in the comments when I discovered this song. Serious question, why is everyone offended that David Guetta, a renowned DJ who has covered more than one artist's tune during his career (like all DJs in the world in the end), and IVE, a Kpop group any young person who shines more and more due to undeniable talent, having collaborated on an apparently famous melody?

I mean, personally, I didn't know this melody at all, I discovered by looking into it a little that it came from a movie. I didn't know the artist either, and honestly, I'm glad I came across DG and IVE's song because without them I would have NEVER known that this man and his melody actually existed.

So yes, the lyrics of this song are more cheerful, at the same time, it's a South Korean girl group, they are there to seduce, to charm. Isn't it rather honorable to have made a real sound on such a captivating melody?

We are still far from the bland French cover of Bella Ciao by Maestro, Maitre Gims and so on. It's not a summer hit that IVE and DG made, it's just a happy, positive collaboration that gives people good vibes. Stop denigrating artists and their work so much out of pity. Or do better.

author: @beacarrilloc
text: Just finished watching the movie for the enth time and Merry Christmas Mr Lawrence always hits hard. I see how a song about a POW camp and how nobody is right during war time can be seen as not great sample material for a pop song. But, there is love in the movie too, yonoi and celliers, hara and Lawrence. The movie itself is about trying to see each other through our differences. Let the kids have fun, just watch the movie and listen to the original.

author: @tene-x1j
text:
A quote from Rolling Stone

Daniel Kim, who produced the collaboration track â€œSupernova Loveâ€ by K-POP group IVE and world-renowned DJ David Guetta, shared his thoughts:
I moved with my family from Korea to Germany when I was five years old, and thatâ€™s when I first experienced â€˜cultural barriersâ€™ firsthand. The film Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence (1983) beautifully captures this theme, showing how love can transcend cultural and social barriers. I was also deeply inspired by the music Ryuichi Sakamoto composed for the film, and I had always wanted to express my admiration for it through a collaboration. So, when we were able to officially incorporate the melody of Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence into Supernova Loveâ€”what we in the music industry call â€˜securing clearanceâ€™â€”I felt incredibly honored and thrilled.
[Omitted]
Releasing Supernova Love was a deeply emotional experience for all of us, especially because Mr. Sakamoto passed away just one month after the concept came together. Dedicating Supernova Love to him and sharing his legacy with future generations for years to come is not just an honor but a responsibility we carry with pride.

author: @gumiami
text: Are the people in the comment section stupid? Lol The whole comment section is so bitter and negative. They even credit Ryuichi Sakamoto in the description. The sampling must be approved by the owner or the company that holds the rights to it. Once the license has been approved to be used, the owner or the company gets a percentage of the revenue or should I say royalties given to them. If they didnâ€™t credit to Ryuichi Sakamoto and sampled without permission, they would have gotten sued, which thereâ€™s no case of them getting sued for plagiarism.

author: @xcsn1
text: The traditional etiquette system in Korea, including the customs of respecting elders and ancestral rites, is significantly influenced by Confucian thought. Traditional festivals, such as the Chunjie/Spring Festival (lunar new year) and Mid-Autumn Festival (chuseok), celebrated in Korea are closely linked to customs that originated in China. For an extended period, Chinese characters served as the official writing system on the Korean Peninsula. The attire of the Joseon Dynasty corresponds to the Ming Dynasty in China, with royal garments being bestowed by the Ming emperors, referred to as "Ming bestowed clothing." Through cultural exchanges, Hanbok has assimilated numerous elements from Ming Dynasty Hanfu. However, the South Korean populace is often reluctant to acknowledge the impact of Chinese culture, even going so far as to alter history. As a 3rd generation overseas Chinese, the concept of "roots" still holds significant importance for me, and the feeling of being robbed is unpleasant.

author: @tene-x1j
text:
A quote from Rolling Stone

Daniel Kim, who produced the collaboration track â€œSupernova Loveâ€ by K-POP group IVE and world-renowned DJ David Guetta, shared his thoughts:
I moved with my family from Korea to Germany when I was five years old, and thatâ€™s when I first experienced â€˜cultural barriersâ€™ firsthand. The film Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence (1983) beautifully captures this theme, showing how love can transcend cultural and social barriers. I was also deeply inspired by the music Ryuichi Sakamoto composed for the film, and I had always wanted to express my admiration for it through a collaboration. So, when we were able to officially incorporate the melody of Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence into Supernova Loveâ€”what we in the music industry call â€˜securing clearanceâ€™â€”I felt incredibly honored and thrilled.
[Omitted]
Releasing Supernova Love was a deeply emotional experience for all of us, especially because Mr. Sakamoto passed away just one month after the concept came together. Dedicating Supernova Love to him and sharing his legacy with future generations for years to come is not just an honor but a responsibility we carry with pride.

text: From various historical periods, Han Chinese, Xiongnu, Caucasians, Cambodians, Polynesians, and Tungus have migrated to the Korean Peninsula, and integrated into this highly Sinicized nation. South Korea is not a monoethnic nation, and it is indisputable that a significant part of South Korea's culture and traditions has its roots in China. South Korea has been a vassal state of China since the Han Dynasty or as early as the Zhou Dynasty. Chinese characters were used by Koreans, until around the 4th century when Korean characters began to emerge. The four major surnames in Koreaâ€”é‡‘ (Kim), æ (Lee), æœ´ (Park), and å´” (Choi)â€”account for nearly half of the population, and these surnames along with some of the less known ones were bestowed by China. Furthermore, South Korea's capital, Seoul, was formerly known as æ¼¢åŸ (Han City). As a vassal state, Koreans wore Chinese æ¼¢æœ (Hanfu), including the controversial Ming dynasty clothing. During the Ming dynasty, Korean nobles wore garments similar to the Chinese emperorâ€™s son, and initially, the nobles were restricted from wearing clothing adorned with gold embroidery. The traditional clothing that is uniquely Korean is actually æœé®®æœ (Joseon-ot)/éŸ“æœ (hanbok). author: @æ˜¯ä¸ªäºº-g1p
text: A vassal state is a country that enjoys complete autonomy but needs to pay annual tribute, such as ancient China's vassal states Korea, Vietnam, Ryukyu etc. They enjoy complete autonomy and can do whatever they want but have to pay protection fees to the suzerain state. A colony is a state occupied, controlled, and exploited by a foreign power, such as today's South Korea and Manchukuo during the World war. These countries can only manage themselves, but all decisions and the military are controlled by the suzerain state, which are often called puppet states. The Japanese would force the Koreans to learn Japanese history, forget their ancestors, and to be proud of being Japanese, and be willing to be second-class citizens of Japan. This kind of education is called "Imperial Education".

author: @hojeongyu223
text: I believe Ryuichi Sakamoto would be very pleased to see his music continuously reinterpreted in various ways. For someone who has reached the stature of a great master, it is likely more fulfilling to bring joy and happiness to a wider audience across generations through his music than to merely preserve its original grandeur. As times change and people evolve, so too must music. If many listeners were reminded of the name Ryuichi Sakamoto upon hearing this piece by IVE, that alone is already a significant achievement.

author: @e60f15
text: Maestro Ryuichi Sakamoto is a truly outstanding composer for the Japanese people, and not only for them but for us, for people in other countries as well. There was a wonderful collaboration between Mr. Ryuichi Sakamoto and Mr. David Sylvian, this is a gorgeous song and a particularly beautiful composition, and in my humble opinion, this ,,Supernova Love'' should not have been made. There is so much pain, sadness, and history in the original version, it is just a shame to remake it like this.

author: @monjuLu
text: I think many Japanese people will find this music and MV unpleasant. You may wonder why, but the song it was sampled from is something that has been familiar to us since we were young, and is like a national anthem. This IVE song seems to have been made for the sake of making it sound good, and it doesn't feel like it was made with any understanding of the original song. Sakamoto's music is deeper and filled with a variety of emotions than IVE's songwriters had expected. If it was clear that there was respect for the original song, Japanese people would have been able to accept it.

author: @alejandradavisr
text: I have seen a lot of comments about this song, and most of them are talking about how this song is basically the same as Ryuichi Sakamoto's "Merry Chrismas in the Battlefield", I myself have listened to the Mr. Sakamoto's song, and it is a beautiful song, with lots of emotion and effort in it. I have seen lot of comments that they should have atleast given some credit to Ryuichi Sakamoto, and they actually did, they have him credit in the writing of the song, (and some other credit which I dont remeber) in Spotify and Youtube, so please stop hating IVE on the aspect of creditation. Another thing that I have seen in this comment section is that they are hating IVE for it, and not the company. IVE probably is unaware of the meaning of the song, and they were probably just following and doing their job. So overall we shouldn't be hating on IVE but instead on the company Starship, I am not saying that we should hate them, but if you are, DONT HATE THE GIRLS. I am a big DIVE, so I would really appreciate if we stopped this fight, and just respect eveyone. Rest In Peace Ryuichi Sakamoto.

author: @æ˜¯ä¸ªäºº-g1p
text: [Nagisa Oshima was a leftist and like many of his contemporaries directed films that were angry criticisms of Japanese society. As such, Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence is a pretty explicit condemnation of Japan being the aggressor during WWII. Scenes such as John Lawrence criticizing the arbitrary rules of the POW camp and his speech to Celliers about Japan being a "nation of anxious people" who can't do anything individually but went "insane en masse" are clearly Oshima's views being expressed on screen. Since most of the film is in English, an uninformed viewer might think this to be a Western critique of Japan, but nope. It's actually a Japanese director criticizing his own country and there are plenty of other films such as Masaki Kobayashi's The Human Condition which explore similar themes.] ğŸ¤”

author: @ìœ ì½©_0203
text:
According to an interview with Rolling Stone, a famous American journal, the producer of the song said Ryuichi Sakamoto died a month after he started working on the song. The work had been carried out for a long time, and it means that the deceased had already allowed sampling before his life. The song is said to have been completed in memory of him. The song is about love that transcends the boundaries of culture. It is also an introduction to a war movie
The essential content deals with humanity and peace
Human love is also a form of love.
The original song has already been sampled several times and claims that it was used without permission
Their claim that the song turned into a meaningless love song is unacceptable. Don't you just want to blame little girls? Please stop the hate and malicious comments ğŸ˜­ğŸ˜­

author: @Zze_611
text: You can dfinitely comment on "it doesn't sound good", but other attacks are unnecessary. Many songs that sample "Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence" have changed the meaning of the song, and there are other musicians who have adapted it into electronic music, but they have not suffered these criticisms for it. If this level of sampling can be so criticized, I really don't understand why other kpop groups' sampled songs wouldn't be so criticized. They are not different.

author: @Zze_611
text:
Starship, please protect your members and don't let these evil intentions expand. Many kpop groups have songs that use samples, such as aespa, newjeans, blackpink, (g)i-dle... many, but they are almost never criticized for "plagiarism" or "changing the meaning of the original song" because of that... that is very unfair, don't let this happen next time please.
The important thing is that according to the website WhoSampled, this song is is licensed from the copyright holder, there are 25 other songs out there. Their attack is baseless.

author: @Zze_611
text: I mean there are many songs in kpop that use sampling. For example, Newjeans has a lot of songs that use sampling. I don't know why the Japanese people in the comment section are so angry. Mr. Ryuichi Sakamoto didn't say that his songs are not allowed to be sampled, he even welcomes it. There were other singers who sampled the song and changed its meaning, so why weren't they attacked like this? I think there are companies manipulating public opinion to attack iveğŸ˜¥

I was known that Ryuichi Sakamoto do not want to sell the sample of the song. I'm not sure about that. Is that real ?

author: @scoooby1514
text: I know that the movie and song "Senjo no Merry Christmas" hold a special space in certain generation of Japanese people. It might be upsetting for them to hear the song like this out of context. But I think it's amazing that more people get to enjoy Mr. Sakmoto's mesmerizing melody. I low-key like how they arranged the pop version here. Must admit it's pretty catchy lol It'd been nicer for them to put Mr. Sakamoto's name from the start so that it doesn't look copycat, but hey, everyone makes mistakes.

author: @wahoomario4323
text:
To all the english speaking fans let me explain the drama to you in the comments
So this piece of music is originally made by Ryuichi Sakamoto who have passed about a year ago(RIP)
But the team behind IVE didn't even credit MR. Sakamoto for his music
The Japanese fans noticed this and got mad in the comments
Now some Koreans fans agree to the Japanese fans and some say they're exaggerating lol
Now 3 days after the posting of this mv that's only they credit Mr. Sakamoto (i think the team behind IVE noticed the drama in the comments)

I think it's fvcked up i think they'll never credit the guy unless it got pinpointed like this smh

Anyways this composition of Mr. Sakamoto is from 1983 the song is called Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence(it's a soundtrack from a movie which the movie is also titled Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence)
The movie i think is about war and so on (i have not seen the movie yet)

And i think that's all about the drama lol

author: @petrinska121
text:
It started as a problem of the agency or the producer, but it has turned into an exchange of bad words between countries, which is very heartbreaking.
We are all same human beings, so why do we have to fight each other so much just because we are of different nationalities?
I think that the movie "Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence"ã€€shows that wars lead people in the wrong direction and cause them to lose their humanity, but that universal human love that transcends nationality and gender do not completely disappears. 
I like Korea, its culture, and Korean people.
I also like other countries.
Of course, I also like Japan.
I believe that we can be friends regardless of nationality or race.
Issues between countries have nothing to do with people becoming friends.
I pray for world peace.

author: @AdelunaNikitina
text:
First I heard the song "IVE, David Guetta - Supernova Love" and I really liked it. It was only later that I found out about the original composition. I think this is good, as more foreigners will learn about the original song, and maybe even watch the movie. I think we need to take the current situation easier.

The original title of the song in Japan Â«Merry Christmas on the BattlefieldÂ». For the rest of the world, this song is called "Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence". From here, one can understand the indignation of the Japanese and Koreans. But I don't think the IVI group wanted to hurt anyone's feelings.

author: @Nara-px8ip
text: Music is subjective, if the song offends you, please accept my sincere apology. The problem is the current copyright holder said "yes". The song that they sampled is https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lNazfECMKcA  "Forbidden Colours" (Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence OST) by Ryuichi Sakamoto and David Sylvian is about Forbidden Love but some viewers interpreted the melody as "Violence against POW". I saw a lot of comments like that, especially from West and Koreans. Perhaps they are concentrating too much on the film's violent aspects, they overlook the heartwarming side such as Hara and Lawrence's friendship and Capt Yonoi's sympathy for POW especially Cellier. The theme song is about longing, desire, sympathy and love. The song is anti war to the Japanese but they don't know that anti war song can also be a love song (google searched). The issue is that they believed Supernova Love is a romantic love song disrespecting the original but the truth is Supernova Love is not romantic at all, just like Forbidden Colours, the song Supernova Love is about longing, desire and love, but the cheerfulness hides its own bitterness. I would cry if it weren't for the song's cheerfulness. (After understanding the lyrics)

Professor Ryuichi Sakamoto dedicated his life to studying music theory. He used his life to translate the horrors of war, which he may have personally experienced, into sound. He did this to make music theory understandable even for those of us who have never learned about or experienced war. 
To rearrange and use this melody in this manner is an insult and utterly unforgivable. Even though he is no longer with us, the experiences he left behind continue to live on through his music.

author: @Nara-px8ip
text: The purpose of the song Supernova Love is to introduce the collaboration of Eastern and Western music. To introduce Mr. Sakamoto to the younger generation through IVE, making sure that Mr. Sakomoto's name will live forever. Mr. Ryuichi Sakamoto's "Merry Christmas Mr Lawrence Instrumental" is the bridge between Eastern and Western music. The song also encourages love and harmony, showing the healthy relationship between the two cultures. Supernova Love's "I need that kind of love. A supernova. . ." is a sort of request that we may or may not accept.

author: @Nara-px8ip
text:
Commented by @valkyrja.d2442
å‚æœ¬é¾ä¸€å…ˆç”Ÿã¯ç”Ÿå‰ã€ã‚µãƒ³ãƒ—ãƒªãƒ³ã‚°ã«åå¯¾ã™ã‚‹å§¿å‹¢ã‚’ç¤ºã—ã¦ã„ã¾ã—ãŸã€‚

æ–­å›ºã¨ã—ã¦ã‚ãªãŸãŸã¡ã‚’æ‹’çµ¶ã—ã€ã“ã®æ›²ã‚’å–ã‚Šä¸‹ã’ã‚‹ã‚ˆã†å¼·ãæ±‚ã‚ã¾ã™ã€‚ã“ã‚Œä»¥ä¸Šã®æ‹¡æ•£ã‚„æµé€šã¯è¨±ã•ã‚Œã¾ã›ã‚“ã€‚
"During his lifetime, Ryuichi Sakamoto expressed his opposition to sampling.
What you are doing blatantly goes against his wishes and is utterly disgusting.
Furthermore, this song was created as an anti-war statement. Modifying it in such a way is nothing less than a desecration of music and art.
We firmly oppose your actions and strongly demand the withdrawal of this song. Stop its further distribution and circulation immediately."

My Reaction:
The purpose of the song Supernova Love is to introduce the collaboration of Eastern and Western music. To introduce Mr. Sakamoto to the younger generation through IVE, making sure that Mr. Sakomoto's name will live forever. Mr. Ryuichi Sakamoto's "Merry Christmas Mr Lawrence Instrumental" is the bridge between Eastern and Western music. The song also encourages love and harmony, showing the healthy relationship between the two cultures. Supernova Love's "I need that kind of love. A supernova. . ." is a sort of request that we may or may not accept.

author: @Nara-px8ip
text:
Supernova Love Meaning and Review
- An anti-war song.
- An Unrequited love song when you have romantic feelings for someone who doesn't feel the same way, such as an enemy.
- An upbeat song that hides its own bitterness. Behind the brightest smiles can hide so much pain.

"Oh, babe, I need that kind of love. A supernova glowin' the dark"
--> I need your supernova love. I don't need your hatred.

"Forever I wished upon a star. Then you came over. Occupied my heart, occupied my heart"
--> I wished upon a star, you came over to occupy my heart. But you came over to occupy my land.

"Touch my body, skin on skin. Gimme every little bit of your love"
--> Caress me, don't touch my body with knife.

"Don't you hold back on me, go all in. I've been waiting for this moment too long"
--> Pointing your knife at me showed that you didn't really hold back.

"One taste and I'm fallin' deep. Caught up in your energy. Never let me go"
--> Am I now your hostage?

"Dee-la-dee-la, da-dee-da-dee-da"
--> Oh my god! I'm going crazy right now.

"Take me to the stars on paper wings. And we'll fly until we reach the sun (ooh)"
--> De - lu - luuuuuuuuuu. . .

author: @ElizabethWang-qr3di
text: IVE just can't stop stealing other countries' cultures. First, it's Chinese culture in "Heya," then Japanese culture. Their actions have pretty well illustrated their unthoughtfulness. Regardless of the original creators behind the music, once IVE chooses to perform it, they take on the responsibility that comes with that decision. Mr. Ryuichi Sakamoto was not only an extraordinary artist but a cultural icon whose work deserves the utmost respect, his songs are masterpieces that should not be used for any kind of remake or sampling.

author: @NoobShutUpAnRun
text:
This is my take on this(not a fan of IVE, David Guetta, or kPOP...just randomly stumbled upon this video in my feed):
Personally, I think it's fine regardless of whatever message/theme is being use(assuming it's not something bad), because at the end of the day, people make things because they want to leave their "mark" that they existed
And what a perfect way to honor someone's work(Ryuichi Sakamoto) is by using it in a way to make "said" work be more known/remembered in some shape/form. It's good to remember the original meaning/use of something...but times still goes on, things change. There's rarely anything, if not, nothing stay stagnant against time.

I do agree that whoever made the video should've credited the sampling to Ryuichi Sakamoto.

TL;DR: What's the point of making a fuss? This could've been WAYYYYY WORSE...could've been about getting money, b*tches, and/or shooting people up :)))
Ya'll be having too much time waste xddd 
Just enjoy what you're given(ITS FREE BTW)

ã‚ãªãŸãŸã¡ãŒã“ã‚Œã‚’è¡Œã†ã“ã¨ã¯ã€æ•…äººã®æ„å¿—ã«é€†ã‚‰ã†è¡Œç‚ºã§ã‚ã‚Šã€éå¸¸ã«ä¸æ„‰å¿«ã§ã™ã€‚
ã•ã‚‰ã«ã€ã“ã®æ›²ã¯åæˆ¦ã®ãƒ¡ãƒƒã‚»ãƒ¼ã‚¸ã‚’è¾¼ã‚ãŸä½œå“ã§ã—ãŸã€‚ãã‚Œã‚’ã“ã®ã‚ˆã†ã«æ”¹å¤‰ã™ã‚‹ã®ã¯ã€éŸ³æ¥½ã¨èŠ¸è¡“ã«å¯¾ã™ã‚‹å†’æ¶œã§ã™ã€‚
æ–­å›ºã¨ã—ã¦ã‚ãªãŸãŸã¡ã‚’æ‹’çµ¶ã—ã€ã“ã®æ›²ã‚’å–ã‚Šä¸‹ã’ã‚‹ã‚ˆã†å¼·ãæ±‚ã‚ã¾ã™ã€‚ã“ã‚Œä»¥ä¸Šã®æ‹¡æ•£ã‚„æµé€šã¯è¨±ã•ã‚Œã¾ã›ã‚“ã€‚
"During his lifetime, Ryuichi Sakamoto expressed his opposition to sampling.
What you are doing blatantly goes against his wishes and is utterly disgusting.
Furthermore, this song was created as an anti-war statement. Modifying it in such a way is nothing less than a desecration of music and art.
We firmly oppose your actions and strongly demand the withdrawal of this song. Stop its further distribution and circulation immediately."

My Reaction:
The purpose of the song Supernova Love is to introduce the collaboration of East and West music. Mr. Ryuichi Sakamoto's "Merry Christmas Mr Lawrence Instrumental" became the bridge between East and West. Introducing Mr. Sakamoto to the younger generation through IVE, making sure that Mr. Sakomoto's name will live forever. The song also encourages love and harmony, showing the healthy relationship between the two cultures.

author: @Nara-px8ip
text:
Supernova Love as an anti-war song "My love, My Enemy". An Unrequited love song when you have romantic feelings for someone who doesn't feel the same way, such as an enemy.

"Oh, babe, I need that kind of love. A supernova glowin' the dark"
I need your supernova love. I don't need your hatred.

"Forever I wished upon a star. Then you came over. Occupied my heart, occupied my heart"
I wished upon a star, you came over to occupy my heart. But you came over to occupy my land.

"Touch my body, skin on skin. Gimme every little bit of your love"
Caress me, don't touch my body with knife.

"Don't you hold back on me, go all in. I've been waiting for this moment too long"
Pointing your knife at me showed that you didn't really hold back.

"One taste and I'm fallin' deep. Caught up in your energy. Never let me go"
Am I now your hostage?

"Dee-la-dee-la, da-dee-da-dee-da"
Oh my god! I'm going crazy right now.

"Take me to the stars on paper wings. And we'll fly until we reach the sun (ooh)"
De - lu - lu

My reaction:
"I really liked Ryuichi Sakamoto, but when I first heard it, I was just annoyed" You like Ryuichi Sakamoto, but you don't like his music? Are you saying that Mr. Ryuichi Sakamoto's music is a piece of shit? Or are you upset that David was unable to transform a piece of garbage into a masterpiece? I think we really have language barrier here.

author: @Nara-px8ip
text:
Commented by @shujimatsuda9735
"This is obviously Merry Christmas Mr Lawrence, composed by Ryuichi Sakamoto. The main musical theme, 6 degree parallel, is deeply connected to the cinema of the same title directed by Nagisa Ohshima. The great movie is about war, violence, and an encounter with a different civilization in the Southern Pacific, starring David Bowie, Ryuichi Sakamoto, and Takeshi Kitano. Ive and their producer should have paid respect to them."

My reaction:
Mr. Ryuichi Sakamoto's music is about violence? This is another "pro war song narrative" in order to defame IVE and Mr Sakamoto. Or maybe there's a language barrier here and misunderstood his/her meaning? But in my opinion turning violent song into love song is good. I watched the film again, but the movie is really about the relationship between the four characters.

author: @Nara-px8ip
text: The film is about a British colonel who tries to prevent bloodshed during World War II by bridging the cultural divide between a British prisoner of war and the Japanese camp commander. There are 19 songs in Merry Christmas Mr Lawrence OST, the one they sampled is "Forbidden Colours". They sampled and interpolated the most iconic instrumental's melody. In an interview they said that Supernova Love is a tribute song to the late composer. The upbeat vibe of the song indicates that his song creates happiness.

De - lu - lu

author: @futureOldie
text: I have an opinion to add and I hope yâ€™all donâ€™t hate me and find me rude but hating this song just makes no sense. I know there are two sides where people are ok with it but others find it disrespectful to the original meaning of the song. But think about, donâ€™t you think this song is promoting the original song â€œMerry Christmas Mr. Lawrenceâ€? I know for sure that there are younger fans that Stan IVE and â€œSupernova Loveâ€ is opening a door to another side of music for them that isnâ€™t KPOP. The first time I heard â€œMerry Christmas Mr. Lawrenceâ€ was about 2 years ago. The rest of the soundtrack was beautiful which allowed me to watch the movie with David Bowie and opened my eyes to a new understanding of war. Iâ€™m sorry for those people who hate because music should be used to unite, not separate.

text:
If I wrote that I felt sadness for this song, I would be insulted, and IVE an artist who is supported by very discriminating people.
 The famous song is a song that has taken root in the hearts of Japanese people, not only in movies, but also in our own lives, with many memories and struggles.
 No matter how many terrible words are delivered this way.
 The sadness I felt with this music will never go away and will never be accepted.

author: @Nara-px8ip
text:
"Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence" is the movie title. British colonel tries to bridge the cultural divides between a British POW and the Japanese camp commander in order to avoid bloodshed. The film deals with the relationships among four men in a Japanese prisoner of war camp during the Second World War.
The song involved is Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence's theme song called "Forbidden Colours" Ryuichi Sakamoto and David Sylvian . Forbidden colours is about forbidden feelings.

author: @ä¸»ä»‹è­·è€…-b5u
text:
For fans of Ryuichi Sakamoto, it hasn't been long enough for them to process his death. A recording of his piano performance before his death was featured and broadcast on NHK, and I'm sure there were many audience members like me who watched it with mixed emotions. There were some parts that seemed more painful than in his heyday, but his performance of Merry Christmas Before War still touches my heart.

I like IVE, and there are some songs that I've listened to many times. So I'm not an anti, but when I heard this song, I was really shocked. I was surprised at the cheap arrangement and worldview, and the fact that it was so easily consumed as a popular song by Korean idols under the pretext of sampling.

I wish someone who knew the professor well when he was alive, like Suga of BTS, and has deep respect for him, had produced it. I wish they had respected the worldview of that movie as well.

author: @U_TnT
text: A Japanese friend told me that the development of the song was set in a war. I already got permission from the family of the original author and already revealed that it was a song by Ryuichi Sakamoto. I think it would have been impossible to keep up with the development of the original song because the song was written not by Abe alone but in collaboration with a famous DJ. Crucially, there are many Japanese in Japan who released the song in the form of a love song based on Ryuichi Sakamoto's song as a motif. And although you can see what the original song means to the Japanese and feel a sense of heterogeneity, it would be nice to think that you can arrange it in this way.

author: @Xianyin.
text:
I donâ€™t usually comment in YT but this time, I would like to know (curious for several days now) since Iâ€™ve read a lot of negative hateful comments here especially from Japanese people/other Asians, saying that itâ€™s a war song and prayer for peace which shouldnâ€™t be sampled/turned to a love song with the rapping, La-la-la, and dancing. However, it was also sampled before by Utada Hikaru titled Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence - FYI (I personally liked her song in YT way back, thatâ€™s why when I first heard Supernova Love it sounded familiar, and didnâ€™t know initially that the original composer is Ryuichi Sakamoto, I also learned that Ryuichi Sakamotoâ€™s name has just been credited in this Supernova Loveâ€™s YT music video description after it was first released) Iâ€™ve searched that she added lyrics to Sakamotoâ€™s melody, using the music as base to explore themes of love, personal devotion, and independence. Some also said itâ€™s in collaboration/with Sakamotoâ€™s permission. Some lyrics of her song in English says â€œI give you my heart, hold on, let me sign it
"Your seÃ±orita, a.k.a. your best friend" (Uh-uh)
Hereby, let it be known
Love like never before
I'm always at your service, you just have to holler at me
NYC, NYC (What, what)
Tokyo, Tokyo (What, what)
Send it off from the streets to the highest
To the highest high
MP3, MP3 (Players)
Work it out, work it out (Hustlers)
You know I (Huh, huh, huh, huh), I'm gonna be yours tonight (Huh, huh, huh-uh-uh)
We're gonna ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh (Huh, huh, huh, huh), ah-ah-ah-ah (Huh, huh, huh-uh-uh)
FYI (Huh, huh, huh, huh), we're gonna be up all night (Huh, huh, huh-uh-uh)
I'll see you later (Huh, huh, huh, huh, huh, huh), call me
You know my numberâ€
Subsequent verses also sounded like a modern love song to me.
Some questions:
If Sakamoto approved of Utada sampling his song with a theme of love during his lifetime, why IVE is not allowed to do the same, is it because they are Koreans/not Japanese with hint of bias? If Sakamoto personally approve Supernova Love as well, then there wonâ€™t be any issues? But there are also reports indicating that for any new usage of his works such as sampling, obtaining formal permission would typically involve his estate or representatives posthumously. Do you think this wasnâ€™t done by the production before releasing the song even though they credited Sakamoto as the composer?
Do the girls deserve this much hate and bashing if they just follow what theyâ€™re advised to perform/just doing their job to entertain?
Is it satisfying to leave hateful comments to this music video which just help to increase the views?
For those who do not like the song or music video, is it necessary to delete it as you said? Why not just stop viewing it after hearing for the 1st-2nd time or just donâ€™t support it at all? Itâ€™s understandable that not everyone will be pleased with everything.
What about those who appreciated this song positively and because of this song, theyâ€™ve come to know and introduced to the original composer and his other creative works, especially the younger generation?
Another thought is, as time goes on, the issue might subside eventually(?) Because there are old hated underrated songs in history that have been later on appreciated and surprisingly got million views today.
And speaking of war and respect, my grandparents were also victims of war during the Japanese occupation in our country, they let my grandfather suffer in Death March, almost shoot him dead on the bridge, physically injured him and psychologically affected him which had an effect on my fatherâ€™s childhood, the Japanese soldiers either burned my civilian grandmotherâ€™s home and made my relativesâ€™ house a torture chamber, but Iâ€™m not hating all Japanese people in general as I love anime, Japanese music, and food with open mind.
If anyoneâ€™s free to say anything bad here then to be honest, I have LSS with this song and I donâ€™t feel sorry for loving it and IVE.
After all, this collaborative project has been described as a celebration of love and cultural fusion, highlighting Sakamotoâ€™s influence on global music.
If you read until here, many thanks for your time reading this long comment.ğŸ˜Š

author: @Ugo415
text:
There are so many songs that have sampled from Merry Christmas, Mr.Lawerence, and a lot of them are love songs. So I donâ€™t understand why IVE turning it into a love song is a problem. Utada Hikariâ€™s â€œFYIâ€ is a love song as well, and according to commenters with no source, Ryuichi Sakamoto gave permission for Utada Hikari to use the main part of the song in â€œFYIâ€.

The only way for me to make sense of this situation is that Japanese donâ€™t like non-Japanese people sampling one of their songs. And if thatâ€™s the case, then What about Chris Brownâ€™s â€œRoses Turn Blueâ€?

Also Check out a song â€œTchiki Tchikiâ€. It is also a song that sampled from Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence.

I can understand if you just donâ€™t like this song, but saying that IVE stole, disrespected, and destroyed Ryuichiâ€™s song is way too much.

author: @0158andy
text:
It's not that it can't be adapted, it's that it shouldn't be adapted in such a Vulgar way, there should be respect for the work of a master musician.

Like Utada Hikaru's adaptation, the lyrics feature Tokyo and New York, echoing the fusion of Eastern and Western cultures, and the piano style is combined with R&B and electronica, paying homage to Ryuichi Sakamoto's original version of the song that was used for the movie soundtrack.

But this song? It's just purely commercial entertainment to me.

author: @jamong_777
@yangxl3839
text: Iâ€™m just pissed off. Ryuichi Sakamotoâ€™s Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence is a classic piece that conveys themes of anti-war and peace, with its melody embodying profound emotions and universal values, showcasing Sakamotoâ€™s legacy as a great ambassador of peace. However, Supernova Love, which samples this iconic piece, transforms it into a shallow and even vulgar love song, failing to carry forward the spirit of the original and, in fact, contradicting its core message. Excellent sampling, as seen in Kanye Westâ€™s Good Life or Stronger, reinterprets the melody to breathe new life into the original work, rather than simply replicating the tune while disregarding its deeper meaning.

author: @jamong_777
text:
To Starship: 
How can it be "written by" Ryuichi if he did not give consent to this collab ? I am genuinely curious.
This is so rude especially given he passed away not so long ago. You can't just put his name at the top of the list and call it a day. There is a reason we "pay due respect" to whomever rightfully deserves it. 


Written by: 
Ryuichi Sakamoto / GODBOY (Daniel Kim) / Britt Pols / Cameron Warren / Giacomo Uber / Johannes Shore / Mikkel Cox (Mike Hawkins) / David Guetta / Tobias Frederiksen (Toby Green)

text:
Now yâ€™all know how it felt to many Americans when IVE sampled Gloria Gaynor for their song that many people found to be mediocre at best (After Like), albeit the subject matter of the song â€œI Will Surviveâ€ is not nearly as profound as that of the song they sample hereâ€¦ 

We oft feel let down by imitations of art, especially when the feelings do not translate into the new work. Such is life.

Sidenote: I actually donâ€™t think this song sounds bad. Itâ€™s only issue is a matter of being a tad tone deaf, BUT David Guetta is very much infamous for that~

author: @Seaoefj
text:
I'm Japanese and all these negative comments against this song, mainly from my compatriots, are a reflection of our conservative and hypocritical society, which kills so many people nowdays. Enough is enough, it's 2024.  We can use the past (even if you don't like it) without forgetting it.

I understand that we Japanese can be conservative about certain things that are important to us, but I think this song was written with respect for the author. Even if I personally don't like this 'Supernova Love' song, I think that's what samples are made for. To bring back to life songs that have marked us in the past. "Merry Christmas, Mr Lawrence" was about war with that magnificent original music. Now it's about love. And maybe one day it will be something else. Music is alive.

And just because the original song is about war, in a war movie, doesn't mean it can't be about love today.
We're too conservative, so much so that we can't do anything without being judged as soon as we dare to 'use' our past.
It's just not right. We should be able to accept the present, without forgetting the past.
Let's stop the hypocrisy, dear Japanese friends.

I hope my English was good enough to make myself understood.

author: @Icequeen1000
text:
The number one reason for all the bad things happening to IVE is her agency, Starship, and unfortunately Starship is on a path that is destroying everything IVE has achieved in her early career. 
It all started after the overwhelming success of the I'VE IVE album and suddenly, without any preliminaries and instead of using this success, Starship started behaving irrationally and stupidly with IVE's subsequent albums!
I'VE Mine was perhaps the worst album in Starship's history in terms of promotion. 
Then, with Ive Switch, Starship promoted it well, but at the same time it chose a concept for the title track Heya that did not fit at all with IVE's popular base in Korea, which is mostly young people, so it chose a traditional folk concept that unfortunately did not achieve any great success in Korea and at the same time brought IVE hatred from China because of the controversy over the cultural elements used in the MV. 
Although these mistakes made by Starship, IVE achieved amazing success in its world tour and finished it by selling out IVE's two concerts at the Tokyo Dome within a few minutes, and there IVE performed "Supernova Love" for the first time, and all IVE fans were waiting for the official release of this song, and we did not expect that Starship would return to the same mistakes again! Despite the millions of dollars that IVE brought to Starship, Starship didn't respect that by not promoting this song properly and by allowing a cheap MV to be released for this song that is not worthy of either IVE, Ryuichi Sakamoto, or David Guetta 
If Starship had promoted Supernove love properly, if they had referenced Ryuichi Sakamoto clearly, and if they had released an MV of IAM and LoveDive's standard, we wouldn't have seen so much anger in the comments.

âš I'm Japanese 
I love IVE, but I wish Ryuichi Sakamoto's name had been included in the title, and as a Japanese person, I'm just sad that it's being used like it was created by IVE. Please, please stop disseminating it as if it were our own song. Please stop blaming Hikaru Utada, as she has obtained permission from the artist herself and is making this with her. Merry Christmas on the Battlefield is a song about war, so why is it a love song? If you haven't heard of Merry Christmas on the Battlefield, please look it up and give it a listen.

text: The main issue is that, at the time of this MVâ€™s release, there was no acknowledgment that the original song was by Ryuichi Sakamoto, which led many people to feel skeptical. After facing a lot of criticism, they added 'Composed by: Ryuichi Sakamoto' in the description, but it remains unclear whether permission was obtained from the company managing Sakamotoâ€™s music rights. I believe Kakao Entertainment should at least make a comment on this matter.

author: @riloy3811
text:
On November 11, a topic titled *â€œThose who spread rumors about IVE turn out to be HYBE fansâ€* was published on the Korean forum Pann Nate, drawing attention. 
According to this topic, it was revealed that 2 notorious accounts, which have been slamming and spreading malicious rumors about IVEâ€™s Jang Wonyoung, are a BTS fan account with 1 million followers and another BTS fan account with over 300,000 followers on the SNS platform X. Meanwhile, a LE SSERAFIM fan base was exposed to make up rumors about another IVE member, Ahn Yujin. 
Upon seeing this topic, many netizens were shocked with the fansâ€™ â€œdirty tacticâ€, with some even suspecting that HYBE have paid fans to monitor and manipulate public opinion to counter competitors, or in this specific case, IVE.

author: @JKumaD
text:
It's weird seeing nationalists in the comments say Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence is a deeply cultural song in Japan, when in the west it is a deeply cultural song too. The film is a queer film about two gay soldiers who find love in the midst of wartime, DAVID BOWIE is there, it's a downright classic that many people have seen over Christmas, studied in class, or had shown to them by a family member. 

It's crazy that the reading of the film is so different in Japan, i'm genuinely curious what the deep and meaningful cultural roots are to this song because in the west it's a queer anthem that represents love beating hate, it's very anti-war, and it makes people feel like crying NOT because they mourn those who have passed by because they have life to live now.

author: @ã¾ãˆ-m3t
text:
I'll explain why many Japanese and Chinese people are so mad at this song. (btw I'm Japanese)
First of all, this original song is senjouno kurisumas(merry Christmas Mr.Lawrence) written by Ryuuichi Sakamoto, who has died in march 2023. what Japanese are concerned abt is that this song was completely used with no permission of him, even though he did not accept using the song before his death. Also, this original song was abt wars, that means rewriting the song abt love is rude and not respectable. What everyone is mad at most is that the credit is not written on the subscription(it's the same thing as copyright in a most horrible wayğŸ˜„)

author: @vuongvuong3892
text:
I really like this song. Right from the first melody, it felt so familiar, but I couldn't remember where Iâ€™d heard it before. After reading some unreasonable comments (mostly), I found out that this sample is from Ryuichi Sakamoto's work. I searched for the original song and listened to it, and it turns out it was a melody I had heard when I was younger.

As an international fan, for me, as long as the song is legally approved (and doesnâ€™t violate any laws), "Supernova Love" is a song I truly enjoy. 

The original track, Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence by Ryuichi Sakamoto, carries a haunting beauty and depth thatâ€™s hard to describe. It gives me a slightly sad feeling, but in a way thatâ€™s also comforting. I feel like both songs, in their own way, bring something unique and moving to listeners.

Apologies if my English isnâ€™t very goodâ€”I hope my words can express what I truly want to say.

author: @hr.2851
text:
Of course, the movie is one of them, but the image of the late Ryuichi Sakamoto playing "Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence" on a piano covered by the tsunami in the disaster area of â€‹â€‹the Great East Japan Earthquake remains in my mind. The song that was sampled is important to Japanese people. There may be young people who learned about it through "Supernova Love," but please pass it on to future generations correctly. I love IVE and K-POP. I want them to make music with love and respect, and I don't want divisions to be created because of things like this.

text:
KDM Records and Virgin Records chose "Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence" by legendary composition Ryuichi Sakamoto as the sampling song for the first song of the "THE COLAB X" project, 
but the Japanese want to get rid of 'Supernova Love' because they don't like the result.
they say that the original song contains the pain of war, but this is a light love song, 
and its English lyrics that have no deep meaning and vulgar POP vibes undermine the original song and hurt them. ğŸ˜®â€ğŸ’¨

disappointed People(Japanese, Korean, Chinese.. in any country)
1. Please convey to the copyright holder what you would like to be careful about when they approve the sampling later.
2. Ask KDM Records and Virgin Records if they can get rid of this Golaboration as you guys would like.

fact : SSE does not have permission to control this collaboration.

æœ€å¾Œã«ç§ã¯diveã§ã™ã€‚IVEã®å…¨å“¡ãŒå¤§å¥½ããªdiveã ã‹ã‚‰ã“ãã€ä»Šå›ã‚³ãƒ¡ãƒ³ãƒˆã•ã›ã¦ã„ãŸã ãã¾ã—ãŸã€‚

I was at DIVE and cheered all the way through.
But when this song came out, it sounded familiar and I immediately recognized it as Merry Christmas at the Battlefield, which all Japanese know.
But I was shocked to see that there were no credits whatsoever.
I question the ethics of the office, and once something like this happens, I will never be able to look at IVE with a flat perspective again.
I am very, very shocked. I think this is a very shameful act to the Japanese people, to the people around the world who love this song, and most of all to Ryuichi Sakamoto, who recently passed away.
I hope that the office will apologize as soon as possible.
Lastly, I am live, and everyone at IVE loves live, which is why I am commenting this time.

author: @winnie_for_you
text: For those of you that think this song is a masterpiece â†’ this song is sampled from a song called â€œMerry Christmas, Mr. Lawranceâ€ by a Japanese composer called Ryuuichi Sakamoto. The problem here is that the whole song is not just sampled, but mimicked with a dull lyrics, with almost NO RESPECT. (The sampled song was  about a soldier in WW2, included the loneliness and its delicateness stood out) Even though the rights are reserved, as a Japanese, I donâ€™t think sampling this song was the right choice to do it.

author: @txtxtxt14
text:
"Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence" was already used as a sampling of songs from various genres. 
Above all, Ryuichi Sakamoto was an artist who did not discriminate against music by genre and dreamed of bringing peace to the world. Those who spread hate by using his name are the ones who actually insult him and his music.

(ìš°íƒ€ë‹¤ íˆì¹´ë£¨ëŠ” ì‚¬ì¹´ëª¨í†  ë¥˜ì´ì¹˜ì”¨ì˜ ìƒì „ì— í—ˆê°€ë¥¼ ì§ì ‘ ë°›ê³  ìˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.) ìì‹ ì´ ì´ ì…ì¥ì´ ë˜ë©´ ì–´ë–¨ê¹Œìš”.  ì„¸ê³„ì ìœ¼ë¡œ ìœ ëª…í•˜ê³  ì•„í‹°ìŠ¤íŠ¸ì˜ ê³¡ì„ ê±°ì˜ ê¾¸ë¦¬ê³  ìŠ¬í”ˆ ê³¡ì„ íŒì ì¸ ëŸ¬ë¸Œì†¡ìœ¼ë¡œ ë˜ì–´, ê°œìš”ë€ì— ì›ê³¡ìì˜ ì´ë¦„ë„ í‘œê¸°ë˜ì§€ ì•Šê³ , í—ˆê°€ë„ ì·¨í•˜ì§€ ì•ŠëŠ”ë‹¤.  ë‚˜ëŠ” IVEì— ë¹„íŒí•˜ì§€ ì•Šì„ ê²ƒì…ë‹ˆë‹¤.  STARSHIPê³¼ David Guettaì— ì‹¤ë§í–ˆìŠµë‹ˆë‹¤.

This song is a sample of "Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence" written by Japanese musician Ryuichi Sakamoto. (Ryuichi Sakamoto is now deceased.) Therefore, the melody was also written by Ryuichi Sakamoto. Also, while "Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence" is the theme song of a movie about war, this song is a pop love song. Currently, the credits are written, but at first, "Ryuichi Sakamoto" was not written in the description. The original composer is deceased, and I wonder if permission was obtained... (Utada Hikaru got permission directly from Ryuichi Sakamoto when he was alive.) How would you feel if you were in this position? A world-famous artist's song was almost plagiarized, a sad song was turned into a pop love song, and the name of the original composer was not written in the description, and no permission was obtained. I do not intend to criticize IVE. I am disappointed in STARSHIP and David Guetta.

author: @CaitlynKeane
text: I think a lot of Koreans do not understand that most Japanese people are just sad that an iconic piece of music is being turned into such a low-class cheap song. Lyrics, rearrangement and MV are all bad. If they actually made a good song with proper music video, the backlash would not be this strong. This just feels extremely disrespectful. I know there are history betwen Korea and Japan and some of the commenters may be leaving bad comments simply because of that feud. But i think most Japanese people, who actually like IVE and do not want to blame IVE for this, do not like this song and wish this to be taken down. And for those asking why not blaming David Guetta, I think Starship and David are equally to blame. It's still more labeled as an IVE song obviously they would more focus on the girls.

author: @CaitlynKeane
text: Starship is doing dirty to Wonyoung again. Always use her for clout and drive hate towards her just as much as Hybe has been. It's a shame that dives pretend they dont know about this and jump on the Wonyoung hate train like they always do. Wonyoung is the reason this group and this company are having meals... This song is also a complete disrepect to Sakamoto Ryuichi and music in general honestly. Dont get me start on what kind of shitty MV is that? I fully support Japanese fans' outrage. Starship please take down this video and dont think what you are doing to Wonyoung is going unnoticed too. She's the only one that can actually bring food to the table. You are already sealing IVE's fate with bad management, shitty taste in music production and all. Hurting Wonyoung will only bring IVE down faster.

author: @Carrotbunbun
text: I find this quite jarring considering "Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence" is a pretty heavy piece dealing with pain, conflict, and reconciliation -- a trauma of humankind. Seeing it being used in such a shallow and frivolous way makes me feel extremely uncomfortable, let alone the fact that the "original" part of this song is so mediocrely composed and lacks beauty and meaning. Btw, as a designer, the visual aesthetics are pretty tragic...

author: @ã‚ã«-b5q
text:
The most iconic melody of this song is , Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence, created by Japanese composer and pianist Ryuichi Sakamoto.
It is dishonest from a copyright perspective that neither his name nor the name of the song is mentioned in this music video.

What would someone who is not familiar with the original work think when they saw this video for the first time? They may mistakenly believe that the most beautiful melody of the song was created by the composer of the IVE.

author: @noufveldon6160
text: The funny thing is that Utada Hikaru sampled this song in 2009 while Ryuchi was still alive. Here are some of the lyrics she wrote using this "Sacred" sample. "You know why, i am going to be yours all night"  "FYI we are going to be up all night".Clearly a sexual song. If Ryuchi was ok with this, then you should be too. He clearly didn't give a fuck. The amount of people whining about how this song is so disrespectful is laughable. The sample wasn't stolen either. It's impossible to steal music from such big record labels like Sony,Columbia, EMI, Warner without them noticing. Which where some of the labels that Ryuchi worked with. I dare you to sample any song from one of these record labels and put it on a music streaming platform. It'll be taken down immediately. So obviously there was a business agreement between both labels (starship and whoever owns Ryuchi's music now). Also, something a lot of you don't understand about the art of sampling is that it gives a song new life. You might not like this song but it will introduce a lot of people to Ryuchi Sakamoto's music. And that's a great thing.

author: @changken1955
text:
In my opinion, this is a typical operation of obviously suspicious cyber attack forces to incite Japanese emotions:

1. At the beginning, many young accounts were used (forged?) Japanese

2. Some accounts that use traditional Chinese attacks began to appear (but their usage habits are obviously not Taiwanese or Hong Kong) (my doubts under several suspicious Chinese comments were deleted)

I know that many real Japanese netizens are starting to oppose it now, but how many of those fake accounts at the beginning were maliciously inciting attacks?

author: @mimsphoria
text:
This song does sound good, but the sample is actually from the late Ryuichi Sakamoto's work "Merry Christmas, Mr Lawrence", composed for for the film, "Merry Christmas, Mr Lawrence", which is a film based on the real life experiences from a prisoner of war during world war 2, thus, the song and the film, both have a historical and emotional connection with many people. 
And so, hearing parts of the song from the late Ryuichi Sakamoto's work, can be seen as disrespectful, as neither credit or consideration of the sample has been mentioned in this song/project. It's like the original meaning and importance of the his work appears to have been ignored.
I personally enjoy IVE's songs, but i hope their company reconsiders their decisions about this song.

It doesn't seem appropriate that a song which originally was about war should be adapted into a dance song... This seems in poor taste.

author: @BluePetal17
text:
Damn, that's such a blatant rip off of Ryuichi Sakamoto's Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence. And IVE even have the audacity to do so 1 year after Sakamoto's death while twisting the theme of "war" into "love," which are polar opposite ideas. It's no wonder that the Japanese are utterly pissed about this.

At the same time, there were also many disapproving comments from other countries. So thank you to the Taiwanese, Hong Kongers, and Chinese who called out the Korean idol group even if they are fans of them. The use of art must always be and remain ethical.

author: @hhinity
text: From day one, everyone has known that 'Supernova Love' samples Ryuichi Sakamoto's iconic piece 'æˆ¦å ´ã®ãƒ¡ãƒªãƒ¼ã‚¯ãƒªã‚¹ãƒã‚¹.' However, the recent wave of negativity surrounding this song is both surprising and disheartening. It seems that many are overlooking the artistry and legacy of the original work, instead choosing to criticize the new rendition without just cause. Music is an ever-evolving art form, and artists often draw inspiration from their predecessors. Rather than diminishing the contributions of contemporary artists, we should celebrate the fresh perspectives they bring to classic music. Why not focus on the creativity and talent in their work instead of spreading negativity?

author: @xuann_0x0
text:
Ryuichi Sakamoto is a Japanese legend and the original title of the song is the same as the movie, Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence, but in Japanese it is called Merry Christmas in the Battlefield. He has been playing this song when he prays for peace. It's well known that he hated sampling during his lifetime and I don't feel any respect for this song. I hope the company will give an official annoucement of this.

 the main problem rn is the company did not credit mr sakamoto even in the ending of the video or in the description. ik they've put his name on other websites and spotify but who would actually go and bother looking at that? The least the company can do is to make an official announcement of that.(Its the basic respect for the one that has ald passed)

this is the official description of the song

-'Supernova Love' is
The feeling when you first fall in love,
Feeling like lightning strikes when the opponent finally shows up when it feels like he's been waiting for someone special for his whole life.
The feeling of the world shining like a million shining stars.
Feelings that love paints our world, shines a light on - a song that expresses the infinite power that love gives us.

Moreover, the song contains an iconic sample of Ryuichi Sakamoto's legendary work, Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence, to deliver a heartfelt tribute to the late composer. "Supernova Love" perfectly combines the nostalgic beauty of the Ryuichi Sakamoto melody with the addictive beat, David Guetta's signature, to create an irresistible dance track.

author: @xuann_0x0
text:
for those don't know/not sure, the original song is about war (World War II) and is known as a famous song that every Japanese person has heard at least once, but at the same time it is also known as a song that should never be taken lightly because of its war theme. However, many people in Japan are dissatisfied of the song because it was presented as a love song that is far different from the theme of the original song, and because it closely resembles the original song(its almost direct copy), even though it is a sampling.

 One part of the argument is that Hikaru Utada s have also sampled the song as a love song in the past(2009), but the most important thing is that the singer has been directly authorized by the composer(Ryuichi Sakamoto) of the original song.

 However, in the case of IVE, the song was written after the composer had already passed away, so the singer did not have direct permission to use the song. And the main problem rn is the company did not credit mr sakamoto even in the ending of the video or in the description. ik they've put his name on other websites and spotify but who would actually go and bother looking at that? The least the company can do is to make an official announcement of that.(Its the basic respect for the one that has ald passed)

author: @ã‚†ã‚†-i4j1e
text:
This comment is not a criticism of the members of IVE.
This silly song is not a masterpiece or anything. Please tell me it's not true, Starship. The original of this song is â€œMerry Christmas Mr. Lawrenceâ€ composed by Ryuichi Sakamoto. It is a song that expresses the misery and cruelty of war. This song is a plea for such a thing to never be repeated again. To those who say that this song is a masterpiece and why it is not more publicized, please know that there were wars in the past and people are still suffering today. But I love IVE!!!

author: @ã½ã‚€ã½ã‚€-t9j
text: This is a rip-off of Ryuichi Sakamoto's "Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence." I can't forgive Starship for sampling an anti-war song into a vulgar love song. I was surprised at how sad and angry I was by the cheap arrangement and worldview, and how quickly it was consumed as a popular song by Korean idols under the pretext of sampling. I wish someone with deep respect had produced it. They should apologize and take down this song.

author: @f.v.7782
text:
I'm Japanese. I want all English-speaking people to know that this song was sampled from Ryuichi Sakamoto's "Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence." If you like this song, please listen to the original song:  https://youtu.be/z9tECKZ60zk?si=_rpCB_VeNrV5mFXF

"Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence" is a song written for the movie of the same title. The movie is set in 1942 during World War II. It is a human drama set in a Japanese prisoner of war camp, depicting the interactions and conflicts between Japanese soldiers and British prisoners of war.

I'm using a translation, so my English may be hard to understand. Thank you for reading my comment.

this is the official description of the song

-'Supernova Love' is
The feeling when you first fall in love,
Feeling like lightning strikes when the opponent finally shows up when it feels like he's been waiting for someone special for his whole life.
The feeling of the world shining like a million shining stars.
Feelings that love paints our world, shines a light on - a song that expresses the infinite power that love gives us.

Moreover, the song contains an iconic sample of Ryuichi Sakamoto's legendary work, Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence, to deliver a heartfelt tribute to the late composer. "Supernova Love" perfectly combines the nostalgic beauty of the Ryuichi Sakamoto melody with the addictive beat, David Guetta's signature, to create an irresistible dance track.

author: @ãã†ã„-p4m
text:
For those who do not understand why this song is criticized in Japan, the original song is about war (World War Il) and is known as a famous song that every Japanese person has heard at least once, but at the same time it is also known as a song that should never be taken lightly because of its war theme However, it is also known as a song that should never be taken lightly because of its war theme. However, many people in Japan are dissatisfied and distrustful of the song because it was presented as a love song that is far removed from the theme of the original song, and because it closely resembles the original song, even though it is a sampling.
One part of the argument is that Japanese singers have also sampled the song as a love song in the past, but the most important thing is that the singer has been directly authorized by the composer of the original song.
However, in the case of IVE, the song was written after the composer had already passed away, so the singer did not have direct permission to use the song.
This point is very different from Japanese sensibilities.

author: @kokoko-i4i
text:
Why did Starship make something like this? How can you put this song out there with impunity? 
The producers made this in one hour? Then it's no wonder it's so good.

This song seems to lack respect for Ryuichi Sakamoto. Before he died, he had said he didn't want to do sampling.
It's fine if it's just rust, but most of the songs are the same melody.
You can make it what you want, but... why did producers put a love lyric on it and It's just a double entendre. Even though it is sampling, but they can't come back and say it's a copy because of how well this is done.
Starship cheapened  original song.
I can see fans getting angry when they read this comment. They will surely say that it is good because they are mentioning Ryuichi Sakamoto's name. But that's not the point.
I wish there was someone out there who understood how this feels...

author: @nana-sk1gl
text:
I dont get why Japanese people go nuts over this song as if sampling is not a thing

1. Its a remake of the original. No one tried to erase the fact that the original exists.
2. The lyrics are in English not in Korean since thats the problem of many japanese people here who cant even understand that they sing in english 
3. Where exactly is the disrespect towards the original song? The girls are dressed beautifully , the lyrics are also well written and the mv doesn't have any aspects of disrespect in any way (except the fact that its on the cheaper side using AI)

Even freaking NASA promoted the song and instead of saying "Thank you for using a Japanese song instead of a Korean one and letting it be heard by younger people in 2024" but all u have on ur mind is how to send  hate words towards the members!!! 

How about all of u chill down and enjoy this good song without comparing it to the original?
(According to the japanese people the original is an anti war song about wanting peace etc but looking at the comments it seems like no one respects the meaning of it in first place)
Also stop pulling another Heya and stealing Chinese culture with this song and Japan.

author: @ãã®ã‚†ã„-o4m
text:
This song was created by Japanese artist Ryuichi Sakamoto.He did not allow sampling during his lifetime, even that Michael Jackson.That is why, as a Japanese, I am very angry at IVE for plagiarizing his song and not even putting the credit on the end roll when he recently passed away and copyright management became ambiguous.Moreover, this song is not a cheap love song; it has been tarnished by IVE.It is unforgivable.

author: @ãƒ•ãƒ©ã‚¤ã‚¢ã‚¸-d9r
text:
This song was made using melody sampled from Merry Christmas Mr.Lawrence, composed by Ryuichi Sakamoto.
The song contains a wish for anti-war and a prayer for peace.
Many Japanese DIVE are really disappointed they arranged the song into an ordinary love song.

author: @jaimecarrera3701
text: I understand that the song 'Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence' is significant because of its connection to war and its cultural context. While I am not Japanese or Asian, I appreciate the profound impact that certain songs can have on a culture. As someone with a hippie mindset, I believe in turning messages of war into messages of love. However, it is essential to acknowledge and respect the original work of Ryuichi Sakamoto. Converting the context of the song might be seen as a positive message of peace, but proper recognition and respect for the original artist's work are crucial.

author: @DeeMonbebe
text: I see. That's why many Japanese people are commenting to this MV.... It's because of Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence. But please don't throw hate comment to Ive and David Guetta. Starship Entertainment will not release a song that doesn't have a permission from the owner or the label. We understand that you have a great attachment to the original version and it holds a great sentimental value, but let's respect one another by accepting the fact that IVE and David Guetta got a chance to make this version, and serves as a great tribute to the original writer of Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence. Let's look at the positive side of this song, and celebrate the great music of Mr. Ryuichi Sakamoto.

author: @kam8460
text:
The comments feel hyperbolic when Utada Hikaru already sampled this for a song about love/sex and nobody said anything.

I'm not arguing that it's not a lazy sample, but many people here are saying the subject matter itself is what is offensive. If you truly value the song as a tragic representation of war, both sets of lyrics should disgust you. Be consistent. It's also logically completely counter to your point as well that Sakamoto had no problem with Utada's frivolous use of his song, to the point that he personally allowed it. Another argument dead and buried. He didn't allow it? His estate did. Take it up with them. Utada and Sakamoto were both born within the borders of Japan so there's a magical connection between them that apparently doesn't extend to Naoi Rei? Yeah, ok. Showing your whole selves out here, huh?

author: @hanwanting
text:
In case you didnâ€™t know, this isnâ€™t the first time Mr. Ryuichi Sakamotoâ€™s "Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence" has been sampled or remixed.

Here are a few examples I selected from Wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merry_Christmas_Mr._Lawrence_(instrumental)):

1. In September 1999, a remix of Sakamoto's "Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence," titled "Heart of Asia," was released in Europe by German-Turkish DJ Quicksilver, under the alias Watergate.
2. A 12-inch vinyl Italo disco cover version was released in 1984 on the Italian record label Discomagic, titled "Clock on 5 â€“ Theme from Furyo."
3. Japanese-American R&B artist Hikaru Utada heavily sampled the theme for her 2009 song "Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence â€“ FYI" from the album This Is the One.
4. In 2009, British singer Faryl Smith recorded a version of the song titled "Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence (Somewhere Far Away)" for her album Wonderland.
5. Tokyo Brass Style, a Japanese big band, recorded a cover of the theme for their fifth album, Brass Style Xmas.

I completely agree that Mr. Ryuichi Sakamotoâ€™s name should be credited in this MV. But letâ€™s not pretend this is the first time a song has been sampled or remixed for other themes.

author: @jiwonliz-x3g
text: I hope you know Supernova love bring  new generation to know and find about the song Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence Ryuichi Sakamoto. And i found how this beautiful melody and meaningful and does't mean they not respect this song. Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence movie shows the relationships of people the conflicts in many dimensions, whether it be different languages, different races, different cultures, different ideas, different beliefs, which can be said to have clear opposite ways of life. no matter what the barriers are, whether it's race, gender, or anything else, we can overcome them with understanding and love, and joy for the lives of those who live in the world with us. So, in the midst of conflict, finding out who is right and who is wrong may not be the only solution in a world where the truth is complex and reproduced. But at least we can hope that we can still offer friendship in a world full of conflict. And about Music around the world too. Be kind and peachful. Thank you.

author: @MK-wj4kj
text:
I love IVE but I am disappointed by this song.
This song samples *Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence*, composed by Ryuichi Sakamoto, one of Japan's greatest musicians. *Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence* is a film depicting interactions between Japanese and American soldiers during World War II. Beyond its beauty as a piece of music, the melody holds special meaning and background, which give it a profound significance. It should not be reduced to just an ordinary love song. The composer, Ryuichi Sakamoto, passed away last year, and during his lifetime he never permitted any sampling of his work. Now, even though the rights holders are allowing sampling and there may be no legal issue, it feels really strange. To be honest, I think it's a desecration of the original piece.

author: @yohohohoho-l2o
text: Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence (Instrumental) by Ryuichi Sakamoto. Soundtrack of the film "Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence". The piano score is a melancholic ballad that perfectly captures the film's themes of loneliness, longing, and forbidden love and that's the reason why the melody and the lyrics of the song Supernova Love makes me feel lonely and yearning, begging for supernova love. There is also a sadness under the cheery vibe of the song. But having a HIVE (Hate IVE) mindset, the song can also be interpreted as disrespectful, inappropriate and plagiarism.

author: @Oharafolk
text: WTF Starship, you start a project involving David Guetta and Ryuichi Sakamoto, legendary figures in west and Japan, with little promotion. You pick or approve a song from a cult japanese movie about WW2, very sensitive topic to be covered by a korean Pop group. Name the song "Supernova" love, as if no one was going to make a comparison or reference to the Aespa's song.  Then release a very lazy and low budget MV made from a chop version of the song where you cut out the few lines that Gaeul had from the beginning, leave out like one line from Liz and put only Wonyoung in the thumbnail for an IVE song. It's like you're inviting all the haters to come.

author: @sama4tha
text: This is such beautiful song, all of the members are always so talented in every single new song that they create, and I never skip any of them because they are all so great! I can't get over Wonyoung's intro, her voice is absolutely breathtaking and almost seems unreal in the beginning! I also loved both Rei's and Wonyoung's rap sequences. Rei's rapping skills and voice in this song were so amazing and gorgeous! I was also happily surprised to see Wonyoung rapping, as I believe that her strongsuit is as a vocalist, however, she sounded so lovely in her rap section and in all of her parts, and it what such a fantastic additon! As well as Leeseo brought so much happiness and positivity with her facial expressions in my opinion, and her such pretty vocals of course! Overall, every single member stood out in so many ways, and the theme for this music video and song is so creative and just gorgeous! This is probably one of my top three favorite songs that they ever created! Sending much love to you all IVE!! ğŸ©·
